content.title: Aortoiliac Occlusive Disease (AIOD)
content.definition: Aortoiliac occlusive disease is atherosclerotic stenosis or occlusion of the infrarenal aorta and/or iliac arteries, causing inflow disease that manifests as claudication of the buttocks, thighs, or calves, and may include erectile dysfunction.

epidemiology.patterns: Can be isolated or combined with infrainguinal disease
epidemiology.leriche_syndrome: Classic triad from aortic bifurcation occlusion

tasc_classification.purpose: Guides treatment approach based on lesion complexity

tasc_b.lesion: Short aortic stenosis, unilateral CIA occlusion, bilateral CIA stenosis 3-10cm

tasc_c.lesion: Bilateral CIA occlusions, EIA stenosis extending to CFA

tasc_d.lesion: Infrarenal aortic occlusion, diffuse disease involving aorta and both iliacs

clinical_presentation.claudication_pattern: Hip, buttock, thigh (proximal to typical calf)

diagnosis.abi: Reduced with exercise (often normal at rest in early disease)
diagnosis.duplex_ultrasound: Initial imaging, limited by body habitus

aortobifemoral_bypass.indications: TASC C/D lesions, failed endovascular, young active patients

extra_anatomic.femorofemoral: Unilateral disease with good donor iliac

content.statement: Aortoiliac Occlusive Disease (AIOD) is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Aortoiliac that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

learning_objectives: Define aortoiliac occlusive disease and Leriche syndrome
Apply TASC classification to treatment planning
Compare endovascular vs surgical treatment options
Describe aortobifemoral bypass technique and outcomes
clinical_pearls: Leriche triad: buttock claudication, absent femoral pulses, erectile dysfunction
TASC A/B lesions favor endovascular, TASC C/D may require surgery
Aortobifemoral bypass has best long-term patency (85-90% at 5 years)
Kissing stent technique used for aortic bifurcation lesions
